module.p: ruith run is a simple verb, denoting an event/activity of manner of motion.

section.p:
The principal parts of ruith are –
ruithidh – future independent, i.e. will run
ruith – past independent, i.e. ran
ruith – verbal noun, i.e. running

section.p:
Some examples –
older pedagogical examples –
Tha mo mhàthair a’ sgrìobhadh litreach gu m’athair a tha air falbh. Thubhairt mo mhàthair, “An téid thu do bhocsa nan litrichean leis an litir seo, Iain?” “Théid,” ars Iain, “falbhaidh mi an dràsda”. “Fuirich gus an dùin mi i is gus an cuir mi seòladh oirre. Ceannaich fhéin stamp agus cuir oirre i.” Tha Iain a’ ruith sìos an rathad leis an litir ’na làimh.
My mother is writing a letter to my father who is away. My mother said, “Will you go to the postbox with this letter, John?” “Yes, I will,” said John, “I will leave now.” “Wait until I seal it and put an address on it. Buy a stamp and put it on it.” John is running down the road with the letter in his hand. td. 5
examples from Gairm –
[...] Dh’fhàs a guth na bu làidir. “Tha aon rud cinnteach, chan fhalbh aon choigreach le mo leanabh. Cha teid i gu aon dannsa, tha sin cinnteach. Tha. Tha. Na bi smaoineachadh gun teid, a leanaibh. Chan eil fhios agad mu ’n deidhinn, mar a th’ agamsa.” “Carson nach do bhàsaich thu o chionn leth-cheud bliadhna,” dh’ éigh Màiri. Bha i smaoineachadh air na gnothaichean ud fhathast! “Greas ort leis an tea,” ars a màthair. Agus, mu dheireadh. “A’ chlann òga an diugh, chan eil fhios dé na smaointean th[a] ruith orra. Tha iad air bhoil, air bhoil.”
[...] Her voice grew louder. “One thing is certain, not one stranger will leave [go out?] with my child. She will not go to a single dance, that is certain. It is. It is. Do not be thinking that you will, child. You don’t know about them, as I do.” “Why did you not die fifty years ago,” shouted Mary. She was still thinking about those matters! “Hurry up with the tea,” said her mother. And, eventually. “The young children today, it is not known what thoughts are running on them. They are in a rage, in a rage.” td. 171, le Iain Mac a’ Ghobhainn

ruith running is a feminine derived common noun.
(bi) a’ ruith be running is a progressive verb compound, with the deverbal noun appearing as the complement of the progressive particle ag.
